gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: sine_wave_gen
Explanation: The purpose of this module is to generate a standard sine wave output. The 'sine' array is initialized with pre-calculated sine values ranging from 0 to 29. For every rising edge of the input clock signal, the 'sine' value at index 'i' is directed to 'data_out' and 'i' is incremented. Once 'i' reaches the end of the array (i.e., i == 29), 'i' is reset back to 0. Consequently, 'data_out' repeatedly cycles through the sine array values, thereby generating a continuous digital approximation of a sine wave.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: [clk]. Explanation: [clk is the input clock signal to the module. It dictates the rhythm of the sine wave generator by determining when the next value of the sine array will be output. On every positive edge of the clock signal, the current index 'i' is increased, moving to the next value in the sine wave cycle.].

Output ports: [data_out]. Explanation: [data_out is a 12-bit wide output port that provides the digital approximation of the sine wave. The sine array values are directed to this output port at every rising edge of the clk input signal. Therefore, data_out essentially forms a digital representation of a sine wave].

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: [sine, i, data_out]. 

Explanation: 
1. [sine]: This is a 12-bit wide, 30-element array used to hold the pre-calculated sine values. These values are essentially the digital approximation of a sine wave. The sine wave is generated by repeatedly outputting these array values in sequence.

2. [i]: This is an integer used as the index to the 'sine' array. 'i' increments by 1 at every positive edge of the clock signal, directing the next value in the 'sine' array to the data_out bus. It allows cycling through the sine array from 0 to 29, which resets back to 0 once it reaches 29, allowing the generation of a continuous sine wave.

3. [data_out]: This is a 12-bit wide internal register connected to the data_out output port. It holds and outputs the current sine value corresponding to the index 'i'. At every rising edge of the clk signal, this register is updated with the new sine array value, forming a digital representation of the sine wave.
